background: Belize was the site of several Mayan city states until their decline at the end of the first millennium A.D. The British and Spanish disputed the region in the 17th and 18th centuries; it formally became the colony of British Honduras in 1854. Territorial disputes between the UK and Guatemala delayed the independence of Belize until 1981. Guatemala refused to recognize the new nation until 1992 and the two countries are involved in an ongoing border dispute. Tourism has become the mainstay of the economy. Current concerns include the country's heavy foreign debt burden, high unemployment, growing involvement in the Mexican and South American drug trade, high crime rates, and one of the highest HIV/AIDS prevalence rates in Central America.

geography.climate: tropical; very hot and humid; rainy season (May to November); dry season (February to May)

environment.currIssues: deforestation; water pollution from sewage, industrial effluents, agricultural runoff; solid and sewage waste disposal

intlAgreements.partyTo: Biodiversity, Climate Change, Climate Change-Kyoto Protocol, Desertification, Endangered Species, Hazardous Wastes, Law of the Sea, Ozone Layer Protection, Ship Pollution, Wetlands, Whaling

geography.location: Central America, bordering the Caribbean Sea, between Guatemala and Mexico
geography.naturalHazards: frequent, devastating hurricanes (June to November) and coastal flooding (especially in south)
geography.naturalResources: arable land potential, timber, fish, hydropower
geography.notes: only country in Central America without a coastline on the North Pacific Ocean
geography.terrain: flat, swampy coastal plain; low mountains in south
